title: Lavender Tallow Balm: I Tried Beef Fat on My Face So You Don't Have To
body:
Okay look. I’m just gonna say it. I put beef fat on my face. On purpose. And I liked it. I’m sitting here, one beer deep, trying to explain why this **grass-fed beef tallow** balm I got isn’t the weirdest thing I’ve ever done to my skin. It’s up there, sure. But it’s winter, my face was basically a flaky, tight mask of regret, and I was desperate. I’d tried the expensive stuff in the fancy jars. You know the ones. Felt nice going on, did absolutely nothing. So I caved and ordered this **lavender tallow balm** from some little Etsy shop. My initial reaction was exactly what you’re thinking: “You want me to rub *what* on my cheeks?” But I’m on my second jar now. So. Yeah.

Here’s the thing. It sounds gross. I get it. The whole concept of **tallow skincare** feels like a step back to, I don’t know, pioneer times. Rendering fat over a fire. But then I started poking around. And it’s not new. It’s ancient. My own grandma, she’d talk about using lard for her hands in the garden. Not the same, but close. People have been using animal fats forever. They just stopped because… marketing, I guess. Because some company figured out how to sell us mineral oil in a pretty bottle for forty bucks.

Anyway. My skin was a disaster. The kind of dry where it hurts to smile. So I opened this jar.

## How Beef Tallow for Skin Stopped Sounding Insane

The jar is small. Cute, actually. It came in the mail on a Thursday. I remember because it was raining and the box was a little damp. Weird detail, but there you go. I opened it. The texture was… not what I expected. I thought it’d be greasy, like bacon grease left in the pan. It wasn’t. It was whipped. Like cool butter, but softer. Kind of waxy at first? But then it just… disappears.

And the smell. They said lavender. It is. But not like a candle or a cheap air freshener. It’s like the actual plant. Herbal. A little earthy. Not sweet. It’s calming, for real. I put it on at night and my brain just goes, “Oh. Bedtime.” Which is a whole other thing—using it as a **night cream** because it’s so **relaxing**. But back to the science-y bit I half-remember.

I went down a rabbit hole. Because I had to justify this to myself. **Tallow skincare benefits** apparently come down to chemistry. Our skin’s natural oil? Sebum? It has a lot of similar fats to what’s in **grass-fed beef tallow**. Something about the fatty acid profile being close. So instead of sitting on top of your skin like a plastic wrap (looking at you, petroleum jelly), this stuff actually gets in there. Your skin recognizes it. It’s like giving your skin back the stuff it’s already trying to make. Especially if you’re older, or stressed, or it’s freezing outside and the heater’s sucking all the moisture out of the room. Which was my whole situation.

This is a tangent but my heater makes this clicking noise. Drives me nuts. Where was I.

Right. So it makes sense. In a weird, “grandma was onto something” way. This **whipped tallow balm** is just taking that old idea and making it… nice. It’s from France, this one. Made from suet, which is a specific fat. Whipped up with some lavender oil and that’s pretty much it. **Natural ingredients** list. Short. I can pronounce everything. That mattered to me more than I thought it would.

## What Happened When I Actually Used It

I was skeptical. I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand first. Waited for a breakout. Nothing. So I got brave. After I washed my face at night, I’d take a little scoop. Rub it between my palms. It melts instantly from your body heat. Then just… pat it on. Cheeks, forehead, neck. The driest parts.

First week, I noticed the tight feeling was gone. Just gone. My face didn’t feel like it was going to crack open anymore. That was the big win.

After a few weeks, something else happened. My skin just looked… calmer. I have these red patches on my cheeks, always have. They’re less angry now. Less “what did you do to me?” and more “oh, we’re fine.” I started using it on my hands too. Because winter turns my knuckles into sandpaper. I’d keep the jar by the bed. Put it on before sleep. My hands don’t crack anymore. It’s that simple.

It’s good for **rough hands**. I read it’s good for **psoriasis** and **sensitive skin** too, which tracks. It doesn’t fight with your skin. It just helps.

The best part is in the morning. There’s no greasy pillow. It absorbs. Really absorbs. My face just feels like my face, but better. Hydrated. Not shiny. Not dry. Just… normal. I forgot what normal felt like.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

Already did. I’m halfway through the second jar. I got one for my mom for Christmas. She called me weird, then she tried it. Now she’s asking for the link.

I don’t do big routines. I don’t have ten steps. I wash my face, I slap on this tallow balm, I go to bed. Sometimes I use it in the morning if it’s really cold out. It’s simple. It works. And for the **anxiety relief** part—the lavender scent thing—I can’t prove it scientifically. But the ritual of it? Taking a minute to actually care for my skin with something that feels honest? That’s **soothing**. It’s not a chore. It’s a tiny moment of calm before the day ends. That’s worth something.

It’s not magic. It won’t make you look 20 again. But if your skin is stressed, dry, sensitive, or just generally pissed off at modern life, this might be the reset it needs. It was for mine.

I got mine from this Etsy shop that just makes this stuff. Small operation. Feels good to buy from that instead of a giant corporation, you know?

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, it sounds wild but it actually is. Because the fats are so similar to what our skin already makes, it absorbs deep and helps repair your skin barrier. It’s not just sitting on top clogging things up. My face has never been happier, honestly.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Nope. That was my biggest fear. But since it’s so similar to sebum, your skin knows what to do with it. It sinks right in. No greasy residue, no breakouts. At least for me and my weirdly combination skin.

**What does lavender tallow balm smell like?**
Like real lavender. Not perfume-y. It’s herbal, earthy, a little green. It’s a calm smell. Not overpowering. Fades pretty quick after you put it on, but that first whiff when you open the jar is just… peaceful. Perfect for a **sleep-promoting** nighttime routine.

Anyway. If your skin’s being difficult, this might be worth a shot. It’s just beef fat and lavender. Sounds strange, works like a charm. My elbows haven’t been this smooth since I was a kid. So yeah. I’m a convert.
